image_credit: Water Resources - Multimedia | U.S. Geological Survey (usgs.gov)
definition: A natural body of water that flows from higher to lower elevations as a result of gravity. Rivers typically flow into lakes or to the ocean but sometimes end due to evaporation or through loss of streamflow to groundwater.
Snow that accumulates seasonally at high latitudes or elevations.
Water that is present as water vapor (water in gaseous form) in the atmosphere above land masses. Water vapor in the atmosphere is invisible to the human eye.
Water that is present as water vapor (water in gaseous form) in the atmosphere above oceans. Water vapor in the atmosphere is invisible to the human eye.Â
A reservoir is a human-made lake. Reservoirs form when a dam is built on a river, allowing water to pool behind the dam.

image_credit: Herring River Estuary, Cape Cod, MA | U.S. Geological Survey (usgs.gov)
definition: Wetlands are areas where the soil is saturated or flooded year-round or during the growing season. Wetlands support the growth of aquatic (water) and terrestrial (land) plants that are adapted to grow in soils with low oxygen.  They include mangroves, marshes (salt, brackish, intermediate, and fresh), swamps, forested wetlands, bogs, wet prairies, prairie potholes, and vernal pools.
Water that is present within soil. The amount of water stored within the soil varies based on precipitation, temperature, and the type of soil.

A lake that contains saline water due to the accumulation of salts as water is lost via evaporation. Most saline lakes exist in closed basins and do not have any outlet, meaning they do not release any water.

image_credit: Water Lake Nature - Free photo on Pixabay
definition: Fresh water accumulates in a low spot on the landscape as a result of surface-water runoff and groundwater seepage, resulting in a lake.
A subsurface layer of soil that contains water and is frozen year-round. Permafrost occurs mostly at high latitudes.
Liquid water stored within cracks and pores in the rock beneath Earth’s surface.

image_credit: File:Grinnell Glacier from summit of Mt Gould 2015 7648 crop.jpg - Wikimedia Commons
definition: At high elevations or latitudes where snowpack persists year-round, the weight of the accumulated snow compresses it into ice. When the ice forms in a steep alpine environment, it slowly flows downhill, forming a glacier. Ice sheets are glaciers that have spread outward to cover an area larger than 50,000 square kilometers.
The upper portion of the ocean that is mixed by wind or by changes in salinity that result from evaporation or ice formation.
The lower portion of the ocean that is not mixed where very little light reaches.

Closed basins are basins where water flows into, but not out of the basin. Streamflow to closed basins does not flow to the ocean. Instead, streamflow ends in terminal lakes, in wetlands, is loss to groundwater, or evaporates. The water continues to move through the water cycle by evaporation or via groundwater recharge. Lakes in closed basins may be saline due to the accumulation of transported salts when water evaporates.
The flow of fresh or saline water from groundwater aquifers to the ocean in coastal areas. Where land and ocean meet there is a mixing of fresh and saline water called the transition zone.

The process by which water is added to groundwater aquifers. Groundwater recharge occurs when water stored on or moving across the land surface infiltrates into the soil and then percolates through the soil to the saturated zone.

We use water from rivers, lakes, reservoirs and groundater aquifers. We use that water to supply our homes and communities. We use it for agricultural irrigation and grazing livestock. We use it in industrial activities like thermoelectric power generate, mining, and aquaculture.
The movement of fresh water from rivers into oceans.

feature_label: Transport of moisture from ocean to land
definition: As air masses over the ocean move over the land, the water vapor stored within those air masses becomes atmospheric moisture over land.

The sum of all processes by which liquid water is converted to water vapor and is released to the atmosphere. This includes evaporation from water bodies and the land surface as well as transpiration by plants.
Water released from clouds in the form of rain, freezing rain, sleet, snow, or hail that falls over the land surface.

image_credit: Water Waves Horizon - Pixabay free pictures
definition: Water released from clouds in the form of rain, freezing rain, sleet, snow, or hail that falls over the ocean.
The conversion of ocean water to water vapor at the interface between the ocean surface and the atmosphere.
The movement of water horizontally between ocean basins and vertically between mixed and deep zones.
